mentions.context: Note that since FastText identifies one language by line, we have always have m ≤ n for every document D.
However, even though FastText word embeddings were released for 157 different languages (Grave et al., 2018), the data itself was never released.

, g m }6 is the set of languages identified by Fast-Text for the document D. When FastText is not able to identify a language for a specific line, for instance because the confidence isn't higher than 0.8, we tag said line with the No Identification Language that we simply note by g 0 .

Furthermore, we define each line l i in a document D as a triplet l k = (g i , p i , s i ) where g i is the language identified by FastText with the highest confidence for the line l i , p i is said confidence and s i is the size in bytes of the line l i .

Both CC-Net and mC4 pipelines proposed methods for filtering "undesired" data: CCNet used small language models trained on Wikipedia and based on the KenLM library (Heafield, 2011) while mC4 used a simple badword filter5 .

On the other hand projects like those of Pennington et al. (2014) or Grave et al. (2018) used crawled data for the pre-training of fixed word embeddings, CamemBERT (Martin et al., 2020) a contextualized model for French successfully used only Crawled data for pre-training, and even large generative language models like T5 have used mainly crawled data successfully (Raffel et al., 2020).

One of the first proposed pipelines to automatically classify Common Crawl by language was that of Grave et al. (2018), which classifies Common Crawl entries at line level using the FastText linear classifier (Joulin et al., 2016;Joulin et al., 2017).
